evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The discriminator favors communication breakdown over procedural deviation due to ongoing communication and coordination attempts.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 shows functional communication equipment was available and used during pushback; H4-H5 indicate procedural deviation rather than mechanical failure or environmental deficiency, supporting availability of communication equipment during pushback.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of communication equipment failure; ambiguity could arise if unseen communication issues existed.

node.statement: Availability of trained personnel qualified to perform pushback according to procedure

assumptions: The tug instructor is qualified and trained to perform pushback according to procedure.
The procedural deviation is inferred from the aircraft moving beyond the TRP despite trained personnel presence.
defeaters: If evidence showed equipment fault traces or bench checks indicating control malfunction, this would favor R4 over R1.
If no trained personnel were present or involved, or if the instructor was not qualified, this would weaken support for R1.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H1-H5) shows trained personnel (instructor and trainee) were present and involved in the pushback, with the instructor taking over and correcting the pushback, indicating availability of trained personnel per procedure. The continued movement beyond the TRP suggests procedural deviation rather than mechanical failure, supporting R1 over R4.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct mechanical fault evidence is provided; ambiguity remains if mechanical failure contributed.

node.statement: Availability of updated pushback procedure documentation to ground crew

assumptions: The continued movement beyond TRP was due to procedural deviation, not mechanical failure
Environmental markings were adequate and visible
Communication among crew was effective and did not cause the deviation
defeaters: If evidence showed equipment fault traces or bench checks indicating mechanical control failure
If marker adequacy or visibility evidence indicated environmental deficiency
If stop-point and continuation behavior indicated communication or coordination failure

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H5 directly documents the pushback procedure and shows the aircraft moved beyond the TRP despite operator control, indicating procedural deviation rather than mechanical failure, environmental marking deficiency, or communication breakdown, thus supporting availability of updated pushback procedure documentation to ground crew.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of equipment faults or environmental marking inadequacy; assumptions made that operator actions were primary cause

node.statement: Mechanical control system components are available and operational when needed

assumptions: No direct evidence of mechanical control component status is provided.
The incident description implies mechanical control failure due to unexpected aircraft movement.
defeaters: Direct evidence of mechanical control components being tested and confirmed operational at the time would change the assessment.
Evidence indicating procedural deviation or communication breakdown as primary cause would reduce support for mechanical failure.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 shows the aircraft moved beyond the tug release point and hit a barrier despite engine idle, suggesting mechanical control failure rather than availability and operational status of mechanical control components. This supports mechanical/control failure and contradicts the claim that components were available and operational when needed.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity

children_spec.statement: Crew members were physically present and reachable during the incident
children_spec.test_procedure: Check crew location logs, communication device status, and witness statements to confirm if crew members were available and reachable

children_spec.statement: Communication devices and systems were operational and accessible to the crew
children_spec.test_procedure: Review maintenance records, system logs, and device functionality tests to verify if communication equipment was working and accessible

children_spec.statement: Crew members were attentive and responsive to communication attempts
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze cockpit voice recordings, crew interviews, and operational data to determine if crew responded appropriately to communication

node.statement: Mechanical components required for control are physically intact and not broken

defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical components were inspected and confirmed intact and functional during the event
If fault codes or hardware diagnostics indicated no mechanical issues
If the aircraft movement beyond TRP was due to procedural or communication errors only

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly shows the aircraft moved beyond the tug release point and hit a barrier despite engine idle, indicating mechanical control components were not intact or functioning properly, contradicting the claim. Communication and procedural evidence (H1-H3) also favor alternative explanations over mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether mechanical failure or procedural/communication issues caused the event

node.statement: Relevant environmental data was not available to the flight crew during the incident

defeaters: If evidence showed that the TRP markings were obscured or not visible to the crew, or if the crew explicitly reported lack of environmental data.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
